antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

changeHistory:
Version	4.37	Publication Date: 10/18/2022
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	1-dose Series -> Select Patient Series -> Minimum Age To Start	18 years	2 years	Lowered begin age due to new ACIP recommendations.
Change	2	1-dose Series -> Indication -> Text Description	Administer to adult travelers (aged 18-64 years) from the United States traveling to an area of active cholera transmission.	Administer to travelers from the United States traveling to an area of active cholera transmission.	Removed age portion of the text description.
Change	3	1-dose Series -> Indication -> Begin Age	18 years	2 years	Lowered begin age due to new ACIP recommendations.
Change	4	1-dose Series -> Dose 1 -> Age	18 years - 4 days | 18 years | 18 years	2 years - 4 days | 2 years | 2 years	Lowered begin age due to new ACIP recommendations.
Change	5	1-dose Series -> Dose 1 -> Preferable Vaccine -> Begin Age	18 years	6 years	Lowered 100 mL usage of this vaccine down to 6 years per package insert and ACIP recommended usage.
Change	6	1-dose Series -> Dose 1 -> New Preferable Vaccine	n/a	Duplciate CVX 174 entry for those between 2 years and 6 years of age.	Created a duplicate CVX 174 for those between the ages of 2 years and 6 years where only 50 mL should be used.
Change	7	1-dose Series -> Dose 1 -> Allowable Vaccine -> Begin Age	18 years	2 years - 4 days	Lowered begin age due to new ACIP recommendations.

Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	1-dose series -> Dose 1 -> Preferable Interval -> Heading	From Previous Dose Administered? Y/N	From Immediate Previous Dose Administered? Y/N	There was a typo in the heading for the interval that needed to be changed to be consistent. The word "immediate" was missing. No functional change in Cholera recommendations or Supporting Data.

Version	4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Effective Date and Cessation Date added to certain Logical Components	Version 4.0 includes support for historical recommendations which requires the selection of relevant supporting data depending on the date of the dose being evaluating or the date the forecast is being made.
Change	2	General Update	N/A	Skip Context added to Conditional Skip	The Conditional Skip requirements for a given dose may vary based on whether an evaluation or forecast is being made.
Change	3	Minimum Age To Start and Maximum Age To Start	N/A	18 years and 65 years respectively	Minimum Age To Start and Maximum Age To Start updated to match the earliest Indication Begin Age and latest Indication End Age

series:
Series Name	Cholera 1-dose series
Target Disease	Cholera
Vaccine Group	Cholera 
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	The Vaxchora package insert states that CVD 103-HgR should not be given to patients who have received oral or parenteral antibiotics in the preceding 14 days, because antibiotics might have activity against the vaccine strain. 
Administrative Guidance	Non-U.S. vaccines (WC-rBS and BivWC) would count as valid only if there is documentation that a complete series with the appropriate dosing has been given.
Administrative Guidance	No data exist on use of the currently available lyophilized CVD 103-HgR formulation in immunocompromised populations.

SERIES GROUP 1 | STANDARD

Start at 6 mo - 17 yrs Pfizer Series	2 or 3-dose primary series plus booster(s). This series is specifically for Pfizer-only primary series administrations.

18 yrs+ Pfizer Series	2-dose primary series plus booster(s) for Pfizer COVID-19 Vaccine. This series is specifically for Pfizer-only primary series administrations

6 mo+ Moderna Series	2-dose series for Moderna plus booster(s) COVID-19 Vaccine 28 days apart. This series is specifically for Moderna-only primary series administrations 

18 yrs+ Janssen Series	1-dose primary series for Janssen plus booster(s)

12 yrs+ Novavax Series	2-dose series plus booster

6 mo+ Mixed Product Series	2 or 3-dose primary series for mixed product COVID-19 Vaccine 28 days apart with booster(s). This series is a catch-all for various mixed product administration patterns and some off-label administrations

WHO-Authorized Series	Includes all WHO-Authorized vaccines and Emergency Use Instructions (EUI) for series completion and booster(s).

18 yrs+ Medicago Clinical Trial Series	2-dose series for Medicago Clinical Trial vaccine including Emergency Use Instructions (EUI) for booster(s).

SERIES GROUP 2 | RISK

Risk IC 5 yrs+ Pfizer Series	Risk 3-dose series plus booster(s) for Pfizer COVID-19 Vaccine for Immunocompromised patients

Risk IC 6 mo+ Moderna Series	Risk 3-dose series plus booster(s) for Moderna COVID-19 Vaccine for Immunocompromised patients

Risk IC 18 yrs+ Janssen Series	Risk 1-dose series  plus booster(s) for Janssen COVID-19 Vaccine for Immunocompromised patients

Risk IC 12 yrs+ Novavax Series	Risk 2-dose series plus booster

Risk IC 6 mo+ Mixed Product Series	Risk 3-dose series  plus booster(s) for mRNA COVID-19 Vaccine for Immunocompromised patients

Risk IC WHO-Authorized Series	Includes all WHO-Authorized vaccines and Emergency Use Instructions (EUI) for series completion and booster(s) for persons who are at increased risk.

Risk IC Medicago Clinical Trial Series	2-dose series for Medicago Clinical Trial vaccine including Emergency Use Instructions (EUI) for booster(s).
changeHistory:
Version	4.4	Publication Date: 01/06/2023
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	All Series -> New Administrative Guidance	n/a	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination, including booster vaccination, at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.	Added Administrative Guidance to highlight an important precaution to defer vaccination until recovery from acute illness.
Change	2	6 mo - 17 yrs Pfizer -> Dose 2 -> Preferable Vaccine 219 -> End Age	5 years	n/a	Per latest guidance as of 12/08/2022, kids who transition into 5 years of age should remain on the 3-dose series rather than transition to an age appropriate product. This means the preferred age for this product for this dose has no specific end age.
Change	3	6 mo - 17 yrs Pfizer -> Dose 2 -> Allowable Vaccine 219 -> End Age	6 years	n/a	Similarly, the allowable end age for CVX 219 has been extended to not have an end age.
Change	4	6 mo - 17 yrs Pfizer -> Dose 3 -> Removed Preferable Vaccine	COVID-19, mRNA, LNP-S, PF, 10 mcg/0.2 mL dose, tris-sucrose (218)	Removed	Per latest guidance as of 12/08/2022, kids who transition into 5 years of age should receive the new bivalent 3rd dose rather than an age appropriate product. This product is no longer preferred, but still allowable.
Change	5	6 mo - 17 yrs Pfizer -> Dose 3 -> Preferable Vaccine 302 -> End Age	5 years	n/a	Per latest guidance as of 12/08/2022, kids who transition into 5 years of age should receive the new bivalent 3rd dose rather than an age appropriate product. This means the preferred age for this product for this dose has no specific end age.
Change	6	6 mo - 17 yrs Pfizer -> Dose 3 -> Allowable Vaccine 302 -> End Age	6 years	n/a	Similarly, the allowable end age for CVX 302 has been extended to not have an end age.
Change	7	6 mo+ Mixed Product -> Dose 3 -> Removed Preferable Vaccines	All possible age appropriate vaccines	Removed the following vaccines: - 207: COVID-19, mRNA, LNP-S, PF, 100 mcg/0.5 mL dose - 208: COVID-19, mRNA, LNP-S, PF, 30 mcg/0.3 mL dose  - 217: COVID-19, mRNA, LNP-S, PF, 30 mcg/0.3 mL dose, tris-sucrose - 218: COVID-19, mRNA, LNP-S, PF, 10 mcg/0.2 mL dose, tris-sucrose - 221: COVID-19, mRNA, LNP-S, PF, 50 mcg/0.5 mL dose	Per latest guidance as of 12/08/2022, kids who transition into 5 years of age should receive the new bivalent 3rd dose or the current Moderna monovalent primary series product rather than any age appropriate product. Removed other products as preferable, but they have remained as allowable.
Change	8	6 mo+ Mixed Product -> Dose 3 -> Preferable Vaccine 228 -> End Age	6 years	n/a	Per latest guidance as of 12/08/2022, kids who transition into 5 years of age should receive the new bivalent 3rd dose or the current Moderna monovalent primary series product rather than an age appropriate product. This means the preferred age for this product for this dose has no specific end age.
Change	9	6 mo+ Mixed Product -> Dose 3 -> Preferable Vaccine 302 -> End Age	5 years	n/a	Per latest guidance as of 12/08/2022, kids who transition into 5 years of age should receive the new bivalent 3rd dose or the current Moderna monovalent primary series product rather than an age appropriate product. This means the preferred age for this product for this dose has no specific end age.
Change	10	6 mo+ Mixed Product -> Dose 3 -> Preferable Vaccine -> Forecast Vaccine type for CVX 228 and 302	N	Y	Per latest guidance as of 12/08/2022, kids who transition into 5 years of age should receive the new bivalent 3rd dose or the current Moderna monovalent primary series product rather than an age appropriate product. Given this, these flags have been turned on to specifically recommend one of these two products.

Doses 3 and 4 supports monovalent boosting and bivalent boosting when monovalent boosting hasn't occurred. Dose 5 supports bivalent boosting when 2 doses of monovalent boosting has occurred.	At the time bivalent boosters are recommended, patients may have received 0, 1, or 2 monovalent boosters. Regardless of previous monovalent boosters, all patients are recommended a bivalent booster.  - For those who received 2 monovalent boosters, Doses 3 and 4 support evaluation of those doses based on the intervals at that time. - For those who received 1 monovalent booster, Dose 3 will support evaluation of those doses based on the intervals at that time.  - Bivalent boosters are overlayed across Dose 3, 4, and 5. Change	1	New Series	n/a	1-dose Janssen Series	New Series for EUA Janssen vaccine
Change	2	2-dose mRNA Series -> Series Preference	3	4	Lowered preference due to new vaccine-specific series (Janssen Series)
Change	3	Contraindications	allergic reaction to polysorbate (186)	allergic reaction to polysorbate 80 (187)	Typo in code. 187 is the correct code and expanded term from "polysorbate" to "polysorbate 80" for new Janssen vaccine.
Change	4	Contraindications	Antigen Contraindication	moved allergic reaction to polysorbate 80 (187) to Vaccine Contraindication for Janssen (CVX 212)	Per ACIP recommendations (3/2/2021) - Contraindication to Janssen vaccine (CVX 212)
Change	5	Contraindications -> Vaccine Contraindications	n/a	Known allergy to Polyethylene glycol [PEG] (188)	Per ACIP recommendations (3/2/2021) - Contraindication to both mRNA vaccines.

Version	4.8
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	All Series -> Dose 2 -> Latest Recommended Interval	n/a	42 days	added per clinical considerations updated on 01/21/2021: https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/info-by-product/clinical-considerations.html 
Change	2	2-dose mRNA Series -> Dose 2 -> Age attributes	18 years	n/a	Removed age requirements on second dose. Age appropriate vaccine should be given 28 days later per clinical considerations updated on 01/21/2021: https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/info-by-product/clinical-considerations.html
Change	3	New Contraindication	n/a	allergic reaction of any severity to polysorbate (Code 187)	added per clinical considerations updated on 01/21/2021: https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/info-by-product/clinical-considerations.html 

Version	4.7
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	New Series	n/a	2-dose Moderna series created	ACIP recommends Moderna, but minimum age and intervals are different than Pfizer and patient should receive Moderna for second dose
Change	2	New Series	n/a	2-dose mRNA series created	Catch-all series in the event a patient receives mixed products and/or receives an Unspecified Formulation. This series is not preferred or best practice, but rather for evaluation when unspecified is documented or mixed-product is administered.
Change	3	2-dose Pfizer Series -> Dose 2 Preferable Interval -> Absolute Minimum Interval	0 days	21 days - 4 days	Change in documentation based on implementer feedback to better support clinical feedback during administration. See next change for more detail. Previous 0 day interval was moved to an Allowable Interval.
Change	4	2-dose Pfizer Series -> Dose 2 Allowable Interval	n/a	0 days	Moved previous 0 day absolute minimum interval into the allowable interval to continue support of ACIP recommendations

Version	4.6
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	n/a	n/a	n/a	New vaccine preventable disease. First supporting data version.

series:
Series Name	Start at 6 mo - 17 yrs Pfizer series
Target Disease	COVID-19
Vaccine Group	COVID-19
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination, including booster vaccination, at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	An 8-week interval between dose 1 and dose 2 for mRNA vaccines may be optimal for some people ages 6 months - 64 years old, especially for males ages 12 - 39 years.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	A conversation between the patient, their guardian(s), and their clinical team or a specialist is strongly encouraged to assist with decisions about the use of COVID-19 vaccines in the setting of MIS-C or MIS-A.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccination does not need to be delayed following receipt of monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma.

Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination, including booster vaccination, at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	An 8-week interval between dose 1 and dose 2 for mRNA vaccines may be optimal for some people ages 6 months - 64 years old, especially for males ages 12 - 39 years.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	A conversation between the patient, their guardian(s), and their clinical team or a specialist is strongly encouraged to assist with decisions about the use of COVID-19 vaccines in the setting of MIS-C or MIS-A.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccination does not need to be delayed following receipt of monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma.

Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination, including booster vaccination, at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	An 8-week interval between dose 1 and dose 2 for mRNA vaccines may be optimal for some people ages 6 months - 64 years old, especially for males ages 12 - 39 years.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	A conversation between the patient, their guardian(s), and their clinical team or a specialist is strongly encouraged to assist with decisions about the use of COVID-19 vaccines in the setting of MIS-C or MIS-A.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccination does not need to be delayed following receipt of monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma.

Series Name	18 yrs+ Janssen series
Target Disease	COVID-19
Vaccine Group	COVID-19
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination, including booster vaccination, at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines on the same day.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	A conversation between the patient, their guardian(s), and their clinical team or a specialist is strongly encouraged to assist with decisions about the use of COVID-19 vaccines in the setting of MIS-C or MIS-A.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccination does not need to be delayed following receipt of monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma.

Target Disease	COVID-19
Vaccine Group	COVID-19
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination, including booster vaccination, at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	A conversation between the patient, their guardian(s), and their clinical team or a specialist is strongly encouraged to assist with decisions about the use of COVID-19 vaccines in the setting of MIS-C or MIS-A.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccination does not need to be delayed following receipt of monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma.

Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination, including booster vaccination, at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	Additional clinical considerations including boosting strategies for persons vaccinated outside the U.S. can be found here: https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/interim-considerations-us.html#appendix-a
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	A conversation between the patient, their guardian(s), and their clinical team or a specialist is strongly encouraged to assist with decisions about the use of COVID-19 vaccines in the setting of MIS-C or MIS-A.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccination does not need to be delayed following receipt of monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma.

Series Name	18 yrs+ Medicago Clinical Trial
Target Disease	COVID-19
Vaccine Group	COVID-19
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination, including booster vaccination, at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	If clinical trial participants have questions about whether they should receive an additional and/or booster dose outside of the clinical trial, they should consult with their healthcare provider. Clinical trial participants who did not receive all the recommended doses, or who received other vaccines not listed above, should consult with their healthcare provider to determine if they should receive an FDA-approved or FDA-authorized COVID-19 vaccine series.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	A conversation between the patient, their guardian(s), and their clinical team or a specialist is strongly encouraged to assist with decisions about the use of COVID-19 vaccines in the setting of MIS-C or MIS-A.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccination does not need to be delayed following receipt of monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma.

Series Name	Risk Immunocompromised 6 mo+ Pfizer series
Target Disease	COVID-19
Vaccine Group	COVID-19
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination, including booster vaccination, at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	A patients clinical team is best positioned to determine the degree of immune compromise and appropriate timing of vaccination.  Factors to consider in assessing the general level of immune competence in a patient include disease severity, duration, clinical stability, complications, comorbidities, and any potentially immune-suppressing treatment.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	A conversation between the patient, their guardian(s), and their clinical team or a specialist is strongly encouraged to assist with decisions about the use of COVID-19 vaccines in the setting of MIS-C or MIS-A.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccination does not need to be delayed following receipt of monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma.

Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Complete defects (147)	Administer to persons who have complete cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., severe combined immunodeficiency [SCID] disease, complete DiGeorge syndrome).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Partial defects (148)	Administer to persons who have partial cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., most patients with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, ataxia- telangiectasia).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	Phagocytic function - Leukocyte adhesion defect, and myeloperoxidase deficiency (153)	Administer to persons who have a phagocytic function defect (e.g. leukocyte adhesion defect and myeloperoxidase deficiency).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	HIV/AIDS - Severely immunocompromised (154)	Administer to persons who have HIV/AIDS and are severely immunocompromised [See the CDC general recommendations for a definition of "severely immunocompromised"].	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	Transplantation (157)	Administer to persons who have received a transplant.	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	Immunosuppressive therapy (158)	Administer to persons who are undergoing immunosuppressive therapy. Immunosuppressive medications include those given to prevent solid organ transplant rejection, human immune mediators like interleukins and colony-stimulating factors, immune modulators like levamisol and BCG bladder-tumor therapy, and medicines like tumor necrosis factor alpha inhibitors and anti-B cell antibodies. 	6 months	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.
Indication	Radiation therapy (159)	Administer to persons who are undergoing radiation therapy.	6 months	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.

Series Name	Risk Immunocompromised 6 mo+ Moderna series
Target Disease	COVID-19
Vaccine Group	COVID-19
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination, including booster vaccination, at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	A patients clinical team is best positioned to determine the degree of immune compromise and appropriate timing of vaccination.  Factors to consider in assessing the general level of immune competence in a patient include disease severity, duration, clinical stability, complications, comorbidities, and any potentially immune-suppressing treatment.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	A conversation between the patient, their guardian(s), and their clinical team or a specialist is strongly encouraged to assist with decisions about the use of COVID-19 vaccines in the setting of MIS-C or MIS-A.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccination does not need to be delayed following receipt of monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma.

Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Complete defects (147)	Administer to persons who have complete cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., severe combined immunodeficiency [SCID] disease, complete DiGeorge syndrome).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Partial defects (148)	Administer to persons who have partial cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., most patients with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, ataxia- telangiectasia).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	Phagocytic function - Leukocyte adhesion defect, and myeloperoxidase deficiency (153)	Administer to persons who have a phagocytic function defect (e.g. leukocyte adhesion defect and myeloperoxidase deficiency).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	HIV/AIDS - Severely immunocompromised (154)	Administer to persons who have HIV/AIDS and are severely immunocompromised [See the CDC general recommendations for a definition of "severely immunocompromised"].	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	Transplantation (157)	Administer to persons who have received a transplant.	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	Immunosuppressive therapy (158)	Administer to persons who are undergoing immunosuppressive therapy. Immunosuppressive medications include those given to prevent solid organ transplant rejection, human immune mediators like interleukins and colony-stimulating factors, immune modulators like levamisol and BCG bladder-tumor therapy, and medicines like tumor necrosis factor alpha inhibitors and anti-B cell antibodies. 	6 months	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.
Indication	Radiation therapy (159)	Administer to persons who are undergoing radiation therapy.	6 months	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.

Series Name	Risk Immunocompromised 18 yrs+ Janssen series
Target Disease	COVID-19
Vaccine Group	COVID-19
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination, including booster vaccination, at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	A patients clinical team is best positioned to determine the degree of immune compromise and appropriate timing of vaccination.  Factors to consider in assessing the general level of immune competence in a patient include disease severity, duration, clinical stability, complications, comorbidities, and any potentially immune-suppressing treatment.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines on the same day.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	A conversation between the patient, their guardian(s), and their clinical team or a specialist is strongly encouraged to assist with decisions about the use of COVID-19 vaccines in the setting of MIS-C or MIS-A.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccination does not need to be delayed following receipt of monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma.

Indication	B-lymphocyte [humoral] - Severe antibody deficiencies (145)	Administer to persons who have severe B-lymphocyte (humoral) - antibody deficiencies (e.g., X-linked agammaglobulinemia and common variable immunodeficiency).	18 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Complete defects (147)	Administer to persons who have complete cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., severe combined immunodeficiency [SCID] disease, complete DiGeorge syndrome).	18 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Partial defects (148)	Administer to persons who have partial cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., most patients with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, ataxia- telangiectasia).	18 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Phagocytic function - Leukocyte adhesion defect, and myeloperoxidase deficiency (153)	Administer to persons who have a phagocytic function defect (e.g. leukocyte adhesion defect and myeloperoxidase deficiency).	18 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	HIV/AIDS - Severely immunocompromised (154)	Administer to persons who have HIV/AIDS and are severely immunocompromised [See the CDC general recommendations for a definition of "severely immunocompromised"].	18 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Transplantation (157)	Administer to persons who have received a transplant.	18 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Immunosuppressive therapy (158)	Administer to persons who are undergoing immunosuppressive therapy. Immunosuppressive medications include those given to prevent solid organ transplant rejection, human immune mediators like interleukins and colony-stimulating factors, immune modulators like levamisol and BCG bladder-tumor therapy, and medicines like tumor necrosis factor alpha inhibitors and anti-B cell antibodies. 	18 years	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.
Indication	Radiation therapy (159)	Administer to persons who are undergoing radiation therapy.	18 years	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.

Series Name	Risk Immunocompromised 12 yrs+ Novavax
Target Disease	COVID-19
Vaccine Group	COVID-19
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination, including booster vaccination, at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	A patients clinical team is best positioned to determine the degree of immune compromise and appropriate timing of vaccination.  Factors to consider in assessing the general level of immune competence in a patient include disease severity, duration, clinical stability, complications, comorbidities, and any potentially immune-suppressing treatment.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	A conversation between the patient, their guardian(s), and their clinical team or a specialist is strongly encouraged to assist with decisions about the use of COVID-19 vaccines in the setting of MIS-C or MIS-A.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccination does not need to be delayed following receipt of monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma.

Indication	Recipient of a hematopoietic stem cell transplant (004)	Administer to recipients of a hematopoietic stem cell transplant [HSCT] within 2 years of successful transplantation.	12 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	B-lymphocyte [humoral] - Severe antibody deficiencies (145)	Administer to persons who have severe B-lymphocyte (humoral) - antibody deficiencies (e.g., X-linked agammaglobulinemia and common variable immunodeficiency).	12 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Complete defects (147)	Administer to persons who have complete cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., severe combined immunodeficiency [SCID] disease, complete DiGeorge syndrome).	12 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Partial defects (148)	Administer to persons who have partial cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., most patients with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, ataxia- telangiectasia).	12 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Phagocytic function - Leukocyte adhesion defect, and myeloperoxidase deficiency (153)	Administer to persons who have a phagocytic function defect (e.g. leukocyte adhesion defect and myeloperoxidase deficiency).	12 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	HIV/AIDS - Severely immunocompromised (154)	Administer to persons who have HIV/AIDS and are severely immunocompromised [See the CDC general recommendations for a definition of "severely immunocompromised"].	12 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Transplantation (157)	Administer to persons who have received a transplant.	12 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Immunosuppressive therapy (158)	Administer to persons who are undergoing immunosuppressive therapy. Immunosuppressive medications include those given to prevent solid organ transplant rejection, human immune mediators like interleukins and colony-stimulating factors, immune modulators like levamisol and BCG bladder-tumor therapy, and medicines like tumor necrosis factor alpha inhibitors and anti-B cell antibodies. 	12 years	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.
Indication	Radiation therapy (159)	Administer to persons who are undergoing radiation therapy.	12 years	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.
Indication	Active treatment for solid tumors (189)	Administer to persons receiving active treatment for solid tumors	12 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Active treatment for hematologic malignancies (190)	Administer to persons receiving active treatment for hematologic malignancies	12 years	n/a	n/a

Series Name	Risk Immunocompromised 6 mo+ Mixed Product series
Target Disease	COVID-19
Vaccine Group	COVID-19
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination, including booster vaccination, at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	A patients clinical team is best positioned to determine the degree of immune compromise and appropriate timing of vaccination.  Factors to consider in assessing the general level of immune competence in a patient include disease severity, duration, clinical stability, complications, comorbidities, and any potentially immune-suppressing treatment.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	A conversation between the patient, their guardian(s), and their clinical team or a specialist is strongly encouraged to assist with decisions about the use of COVID-19 vaccines in the setting of MIS-C or MIS-A.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccination does not need to be delayed following receipt of monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma.

Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Complete defects (147)	Administer to persons who have complete cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., severe combined immunodeficiency [SCID] disease, complete DiGeorge syndrome).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Partial defects (148)	Administer to persons who have partial cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., most patients with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, ataxia- telangiectasia).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	Phagocytic function - Leukocyte adhesion defect, and myeloperoxidase deficiency (153)	Administer to persons who have a phagocytic function defect (e.g. leukocyte adhesion defect and myeloperoxidase deficiency).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	HIV/AIDS - Severely immunocompromised (154)	Administer to persons who have HIV/AIDS and are severely immunocompromised [See the CDC general recommendations for a definition of "severely immunocompromised"].	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	Transplantation (157)	Administer to persons who have received a transplant.	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	Immunosuppressive therapy (158)	Administer to persons who are undergoing immunosuppressive therapy. Immunosuppressive medications include those given to prevent solid organ transplant rejection, human immune mediators like interleukins and colony-stimulating factors, immune modulators like levamisol and BCG bladder-tumor therapy, and medicines like tumor necrosis factor alpha inhibitors and anti-B cell antibodies. 	6 months	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.
Indication	Radiation therapy (159)	Administer to persons who are undergoing radiation therapy.	6 months	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.

Series Name	Risk Immunocompromised WHO-Authorized series
Target Disease	COVID-19
Vaccine Group	COVID-19
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination, including booster vaccination, at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	Additional clinical considerations including boosting strategies for persons vaccinated outside the U.S. can be found here: https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/interim-considerations-us.html#appendix-a
Administrative Guidance	A patients clinical team is best positioned to determine the degree of immune compromise and appropriate timing of vaccination.  Factors to consider in assessing the general level of immune competence in a patient include disease severity, duration, clinical stability, complications, comorbidities, and any potentially immune-suppressing treatment.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	A conversation between the patient, their guardian(s), and their clinical team or a specialist is strongly encouraged to assist with decisions about the use of COVID-19 vaccines in the setting of MIS-C or MIS-A.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccination does not need to be delayed following receipt of monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma.

Indication	B-lymphocyte [humoral] - Severe antibody deficiencies (145)	Administer to persons who have severe B-lymphocyte (humoral) - antibody deficiencies (e.g., X-linked agammaglobulinemia and common variable immunodeficiency).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Complete defects (147)	Administer to persons who have complete cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., severe combined immunodeficiency [SCID] disease, complete DiGeorge syndrome).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Partial defects (148)	Administer to persons who have partial cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., most patients with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, ataxia- telangiectasia).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	Phagocytic function - Leukocyte adhesion defect, and myeloperoxidase deficiency (153)	Administer to persons who have a phagocytic function defect (e.g. leukocyte adhesion defect and myeloperoxidase deficiency).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	HIV/AIDS - Severely immunocompromised (154)	Administer to persons who have HIV/AIDS and are severely immunocompromised [See the CDC general recommendations for a definition of "severely immunocompromised"].	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	Transplantation (157)	Administer to persons who have received a transplant.	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	Immunosuppressive therapy (158)	Administer to persons who are undergoing immunosuppressive therapy. Immunosuppressive medications include those given to prevent solid organ transplant rejection, human immune mediators like interleukins and colony-stimulating factors, immune modulators like levamisol and BCG bladder-tumor therapy, and medicines like tumor necrosis factor alpha inhibitors and anti-B cell antibodies. 	6 months	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.
Indication	Radiation therapy (159)	Administer to persons who are undergoing radiation therapy.	6 months	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.

Series Name	Risk Immunocompromised 18 yrs+ Medicago Clinical Trial Series
Target Disease	COVID-19
Vaccine Group	COVID-19
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination, including booster vaccination, at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	If clinical trial participants have questions about whether they should receive an additional and/or booster dose outside of the clinical trial, they should consult with their healthcare provider. Clinical trial participants who did not receive all the recommended doses, or who received other vaccines not listed above, should consult with their healthcare provider to determine if they should receive an FDA-approved or FDA-authorized COVID-19 vaccine series.
Administrative Guidance	A patients clinical team is best positioned to determine the degree of immune compromise and appropriate timing of vaccination.  Factors to consider in assessing the general level of immune competence in a patient include disease severity, duration, clinical stability, complications, comorbidities, and any potentially immune-suppressing treatment.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	A conversation between the patient, their guardian(s), and their clinical team or a specialist is strongly encouraged to assist with decisions about the use of COVID-19 vaccines in the setting of MIS-C or MIS-A.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccination does not need to be delayed following receipt of monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma.

Indication	B-lymphocyte [humoral] - Severe antibody deficiencies (145)	Administer to persons who have severe B-lymphocyte (humoral) - antibody deficiencies (e.g., X-linked agammaglobulinemia and common variable immunodeficiency).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Complete defects (147)	Administer to persons who have complete cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., severe combined immunodeficiency [SCID] disease, complete DiGeorge syndrome).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Partial defects (148)	Administer to persons who have partial cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., most patients with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, ataxia- telangiectasia).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	Phagocytic function - Leukocyte adhesion defect, and myeloperoxidase deficiency (153)	Administer to persons who have a phagocytic function defect (e.g. leukocyte adhesion defect and myeloperoxidase deficiency).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	HIV/AIDS - Severely immunocompromised (154)	Administer to persons who have HIV/AIDS and are severely immunocompromised [See the CDC general recommendations for a definition of "severely immunocompromised"].	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	Transplantation (157)	Administer to persons who have received a transplant.	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	Immunosuppressive therapy (158)	Administer to persons who are undergoing immunosuppressive therapy. Immunosuppressive medications include those given to prevent solid organ transplant rejection, human immune mediators like interleukins and colony-stimulating factors, immune modulators like levamisol and BCG bladder-tumor therapy, and medicines like tumor necrosis factor alpha inhibitors and anti-B cell antibodies. 	6 months	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.
Indication	Radiation therapy (159)	Administer to persons who are undergoing radiation therapy.	6 months	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	Dengue Vaccine - Recommendations of the ACIP, United States, 2021 - https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/70/rr/pdfs/rr7006a1-H.pdf
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

Antigen Contraindication	Adverse reaction to vaccine component (080)	Do not vaccinate if the patient has had an adverse reaction to a vaccine component.	n/a	n/a	n/a
Antigen Contraindication	B-lymphocyte [humoral] - Severe antibody deficiencies (145)	Do not vaccinate if the patient has severe B-lymphocyte (humoral) - antibody deficiencies (e.g., X-linked agammaglobulinemia and common variable immunodeficiency).	n/a	n/a	n/a
Antigen Contraindication	B-lymphocyte [humoral] - Less severe antibody deficiencies (146)	Do not vaccinate if the patient has less severe B-lymphocyte (humoral) - antibody deficiencies (e.g., selective IgA deficiency and IgG subclass deficiency).	n/a	n/a	n/a
Antigen Contraindication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Complete defects (147)	Do not vaccinate if the patient has complete cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., severe combined immunodeficiency [SCID] disease, complete DiGeorge syndrome).	n/a	n/a	n/a
Antigen Contraindication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Partial defects (148)	Do not vaccinate if the patient has partial cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., most patients with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, ataxia- telangiectasia).	n/a	n/a	n/a
Antigen Contraindication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - interferon-gamma or interferon-alpha (150)	Do not vaccinate if the patient has cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects related to interferon-gamma or interferon-alpha	n/a	n/a	n/a
Antigen Contraindication	Phagocytic function - Leukocyte adhesion defect, and myeloperoxidase deficiency (153)	Do not vaccinate if the patient has a phagocytic function defect (e.g. leukocyte adhesion defect and myeloperoxidase deficiency).	n/a	n/a	n/a
Antigen Contraindication	HIV/AIDS - severely immunocompromised (154)	Do not vaccinate if the patient has HIV/AIDS and is severely immunocompromised (See the CDC general recommendations for a definition of "severely immunocompromised").	n/a	n/a	n/a
Antigen Contraindication	Generalized malignant neoplasm (156)	Do not vaccinate if the patient has generalized malignant neoplasm.	n/a	n/a	n/a
Antigen Contraindication	Transplantation (157)	Do not vaccinate if the patient received a transplant.	n/a	n/a	n/a
Antigen Contraindication	Immunosuppressive therapy (158)	Do not vaccinate if the patient is undergoing immunosuppressive therapy. Immunosuppressive medications include those given to prevent solid organ transplant rejection, human immune mediators like interleukins and colony-stimulating factors, immune modulators like levamisol and BCG bladder-tumor therapy, and medicines like tumor necrosis factor alpha inhibitors and anti-B cell antibodies. 	n/a	n/a	n/a
Antigen Contraindication	Radiation therapy (159)	Do not vaccinate if the patient is undergoing radiation therapy.	n/a	n/a	n/a
Antigen Contraindication	Severe allergic reaction after previous dose of Dengue vaccine (210)	Do not vaccinate if the patient has had a severe allergic reaction after a previous dose of Dengue vaccine.	n/a	n/a	n/a

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

Standard Series	This series starts with the standard 5 dose series for children < 7 years old.  It includes the ability to skip the 5th dose if the 4th dose is administered after 4 years.
Diphtheria standard series	Doses 6, 7, and 8 address adolescent doses of Tdap/Td based on the number of valid doses received < 7 years. 
Diphtheria standard series	Dose 9 is the adolescent (11-12 year) dose.
Diphtheria standard series	Dose 10 is the recurring dose

Start at 12 months Series	This series has the same structure as the standard series, but is for patients who receive their first dose on or after 12 months of age. 
	Doses 1-5 are the the standard 5 dose series for children < 7 years old.  It includes the ability to skip the 5th dose if the 4th dose is administered after 4 years.
Diphtheria standard series	Doses 6, 7, and 8 address adolescent doses of Tdap/Td based on the number of valid doses received < 7 years. 
Diphtheria standard series	Dose 9 is the adolescent (11-12 year) dose.
Diphtheria standard series	Dose 10 is the recurring dose

Change	Change #	Area	Previous 	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Dose 6, 7, and 8 Skip Dose Trigger Age	11 years	removed 11 years and set to "n/a"	Doses 6, 7, 8 are the catch-up doses for Tdap/Td when DTaP was not fully administered.  These doses are still recommended for completion past 11 years so they should not have been skipped.  Removing the skip dose trigger age allows these recommendations to be met.
Change	2	Doses 1 - 5 Skip Dose Trigger Doses Administered	N/A	Added support for 6 doses by 7 years in DTaP	A 1991 MMWR statement for DTP recommends a maximum of 6 doses prior to 7 years of age regardless of validity.

Version	1.7
Change	Change #	Area	Previous 	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Dose 4 Allowable Interval	not populated.  New logical component in version 1.7	4 months	4 months, which is acknowledged as an allowable interval was previously specified in the "Absolute Minimum Interval" on the interval logical component.  This worked in all cases except when spacing from a not valid interval.  The new allowable interval fixes this and allows the 4 month interval even from an invalid dose.

Version	1.5
Change	Change #	Area	Previous 	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Allowable Vaccine on all doses	All DTaP containing  vaccines had a vaccine type end age of 11 years	Changed to 19 years for all DTaP containing vaccines	Per 2014 Childhood/Adolescent Harmonized schedule - DTaP can be inadvertently administered through 18 years (less than 19 years) and be counted as the adolescent Tdap booster dose.

Version	1.4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous 	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Allowable Vaccine on last dose	Only Td and Tdap based vaccines were listed as allowable vaccines	Carried all allowable vaccines from the previous dose down to the last dose.	Since the last dose could actually be administered at 7 years old, an allowable administration of DTaP and other allowable vaccines in the previous dose could still be administered and be considered valid.
Change	2	Skip Dose on Dose 9 in Series	N/A	Added a Trigger Target Dose value of 8 to properly skip the adolescent dose (dose 9) if dose 8 was satisifed	Td can be either recommended starting at 7 or 11 years depending upon DTaP administrations.  Previously, the supporting data would recommend a dose at 7 AND at 11 in certain situations.  This allows for skipping the 11 year recommendation if the child is recommended and receives dose(s) between 7 through 10 years.  Either dose 8 or 9 must be satisfied, but not both.
Change	3	Interval on Dose 9	Interval was specified	Removed Interval on 11 year Adolescent dose	A child who is "fully vaccinated" for DTaP by age 7 years is to be recommended for Tdap at age 11 years without regard to interval.  Similarly, the adolescent dose of Tdap can be administered without regard to interval from the last DTaP dose.  This is not the case, however, when the child enters age 7 years and is not fully vaccinated for DTaP and this is addressed in dose 6, 7, and 8 (catch-up doses) in the series.
Change	4	Dose 10	Not Specified in previous version.	Dose 10 added	Previously Dose 9 was the adolescent dose as well as the recurring 10 year booster dose.  These two requirements were separated into two different doses. Dose 9 is now the adolescent dose and Dose 10 is the recurring 10 year booster.

Version	1.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous 	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Latest Recommended Interval on Dose 9	N/A	10 years + 4 weeks	Based on clarification from NIPInfo.

Version	1.1
Change	Change #	Area	Previous 	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Updates	N/A	Added "Overview" section to Overview tab.  Cleaned up vaccine names in overview table and "series" tabs.	Inconsistencies between Vaccine table in overview tab and "series" tabs
Change	2	Preferable and Allowable Vaccines	N/A	Improved dilineation between preferrable and allowable vaccines through clear age range definition	Consistency effort across all antigens to clearly define preferred vaccines which should be given and allowable vaccines which can be given.
Change	3	Substitute Dose	Missing conditions	Added substitutions to dose 6 for a child who is up-to-date to properly substitute the catch-up doses	A child who is up-to-date at age 7, doesn't need to go through the catch-up doses (6, 7, and 8).  This was missing in version 1.0 and forcing the child through the catch-up doses.
Change	4	Catch-up Doses 6 - 8 Latest Recommended Age and Latest Recommended Intervals	Values not specified	Added Latest Recommended Age and Latest Recommended Intervals to match the Earliest Recommended Age and Earliest Recommended Intervals for each dose.	These were empty before which resulted in a forecast with no Past Due Date.  Since the child is in catch-up at this point, the Past Due Date should align with the Recommended Date.
Change	5	Age Values on Dose 9	Values not specified	Absolute Minimum Age: 7 years Minimum Age: 11 Years Earliest Recommended Age: 11 Years Latest Recommended Age: 13 Years	There were no age values on the recurring dose which resulted in the 11 year dose for a child who was up-to-date with childhood DTaP as incorrect.

FAQs	Where can I find the most recent ACIP recommendations for tetanus?	The CDC publishes the most recent ACIP vaccine recommendations.	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/dtap.html  http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/tdap-td.html	n/a
FAQs	Where can I find answers to my questions about diphtheria?	The Immunization Action Coalition hosts a web site answering common questions about immunizations	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_diph.asp	n/a
FAQs	Is there a maximum number of doses of DTaP a child should receive?	ACIP recommends that children receive no more than 6 doses of diphtheria and tetanus toxoids (e.g., DT, DTaP, DTP) before the seventh birthday because of concern about adverse reactions, primarily local reactions	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_tet.asp	Each of the first 5 doses in the standard series has Conditional Skip logic indicating that receiving 6 or more doses before the age of the 7 is sufficient grounds for skipping the dose.

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.

faq:
FAQs	Question	Answer	Reference	CDSi Manifestation
FAQs	Where can I find the most recent ACIP recommendations for hepatitis A?	The CDC publishes the most recent ACIP vaccine recommendations.	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/hepa.html	n/a
FAQs	Where can I find answers to my questions about hepatitis A?	The Immunization Action Coalition hosts a web site answering common questions about immunizations	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_hepa.asp	n/a
FAQs	Single antigen HepA vaccine is an Allowable Vaccine for all doses in the 3-dose Twinrix series. Doesn't that mean that an individual could complete the Twinrix series without getting any doses of Twinrix?	Yes, a subject matter expert at the CDC confirmed that an individual would be considered fully protected with 3 doses of HepA single antigen vaccine on the Twinrix schedule. Because this schedule is intended for use with Twinrix, we have elected to keep the tradename in the series name.	n/a	HepA is allowable for all 3 doses in the Twinrix 3-dose series.
FAQs	In the 2-dose series, the Preferable Interval and Allowable Interval look suspiciously like the same thing, why are both necessary?	The Preferable Interval is 6 months from the immediately previous dose which may be invalid if an attempted second dose was administered before 6 months. However the April 2017 ACIP Best Practice Guidelines notes an administration pattern where if the last dose is separated by 6 months from the 1st dose, Hep A can be considered complete. The Allowable Interval accounts for this possibility.	https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/timing.html	Both the Preferable and Allowable interval is populated for dose 2 of a 2-dose series.
FAQs	In the Risk 2-dose series why are CVX codes 83 and 104 allowable for the first dose but not the second dose?	Doses of CVX 83 and 104 contain a lower dose of antigen which is only valid for persons under the age of 19 years. The 2-dose risk series for adults only, but if a patient received one dose before the age of 19 years it still counts towards completion of the first dose of the series. It is expected that the second dose will occur after the age of 19 years (otherwise the patient will have completed the equivalent 2-dose standard series) and so these CVX codes will not be valid.	n/a	CVX codes 83 and 104 are only allowable for the first dose.
FAQs	How can the supporting data be used to recommend Hepatitis A to all adults?	Once support of risk series is implemented, by assigning an indication of "Patient seeks protection (001)" to all individuals of the appropriate age, vaccination against Hepatitis A will be recommended.	n/a	n/a
FAQs	Is there a minimum interval between the infant travel dose (6 through 11 months) from the Risk 1-dose series and the initial dose of the standard 2-dose series?	No, there is no minimum interval between those two doses.	CDC subject matter experts	Dose 1 of the standard 2-dose series has no minimum interval

The first dose of the HepA vaccine series should be administered as soon as adoption is planned, ideally 2 or more weeks before the arrival of the adoptee
Indication	Occupational exposure for Hepatitis A (059)	Administer to persons who have an occupational exposure for Hepatitis A	19 years	n/a	Includes persons who work with HAV-infected nonhuman primates or with clinical or nonclinical material containing HAV in a research laboratory setting should be vaccinated. No other occupational groups (e.g., health care providers or food handlers) have been demonstrated to be at increased risk for HAV infection because of occupational exposure
Indication	Persons at risk during an outbreak (070)	Administer to persons identified as at increased risk during a community outbreak attributable to a vaccine serogroup.	19 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Homelessness (121)	Administer to persons who are experiencing homelessness.	19 years	n/a	A homeless person is defined as 1) a person who lacks housing (regardless of whether the person is a member of a family), including a person whose primary residence during the night is a supervised public or private facility (e.g., shelter) that provides temporary living accommodations and a person who is a resident in transitional housing, 2) a person without permanent housing who might live on the streets; or stay in a shelter, mission, single-room occupancy facility, abandoned building, vehicle, or any other unstable or nonpermanent situation, or 3) who is doubled up, a term that refers to a situation where persons are unable to maintain their housing situation and are forced to stay with a series of friends or extended family members. In addition, previously homeless persons who are to be released from a prison or a hospital might be considered homeless if they do not have a stable housing situation to which they can return.

The first dose of the HepA vaccine series should be administered as soon as adoption is planned, ideally 2 or more weeks before the arrival of the adoptee
Indication	Occupational exposure for Hepatitis A (059)	Administer to persons who have an occupational exposure for Hepatitis A	19 years	n/a	Includes persons who work with HAV-infected nonhuman primates or with clinical or nonclinical material containing HAV in a research laboratory setting should be vaccinated. No other occupational groups (e.g., health care providers or food handlers) have been demonstrated to be at increased risk for HAV infection because of occupational exposure
Indication	Persons at risk during an outbreak (070)	Administer to persons identified as at increased risk during a community outbreak attributable to a vaccine serogroup.	19 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Homelessness (121)	Administer to persons who are experiencing homelessness.	19 years	n/a	A homeless person is defined as 1) a person who lacks housing (regardless of whether the person is a member of a family), including a person whose primary residence during the night is a supervised public or private facility (e.g., shelter) that provides temporary living accommodations and a person who is a resident in transitional housing, 2) a person without permanent housing who might live on the streets; or stay in a shelter, mission, single-room occupancy facility, abandoned building, vehicle, or any other unstable or nonpermanent situation, or 3) who is doubled up, a term that refers to a situation where persons are unable to maintain their housing situation and are forced to stay with a series of friends or extended family members. In addition, previously homeless persons who are to be released from a prison or a hospital might be considered homeless if they do not have a stable housing situation to which they can return.
Indication	Travel to or working in countries that have high or intermediate endemicity of Hepatitis A (142)	Administer to persons traveling to or working in countries that have high or intermediate endemicity of Hepatitis A.	19 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Patient seeks Hepatitis A  protection (175)	Administer to persons seeking protection from Hepatitis A.	19 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Persons in settings that provide services to adults with high proportion of those persons have risk factors for HAV infection (185)	Administer to persons in settings that provider services to adults with high proportion of those persons have risk factors HAV infection	19 years	n/a	Settings in which a high proportion of persons have risk factors for HAV infection include health care settings that focus on persons who use injection or noninjection drugs, as well as group homes and nonresidential day care facilities for persons with developmental disabilities
Indication	HIV Infection (186)	Administer to persons with HIV Infection	19 years	n/a	n/a
